title: The retention problem: Women are going into tech but are also being driven out

last_post.content:
"We found that women flourish when supported by community guidelines, such as the codes of conduct for online spaces, in-person events & professional organizations. We found that codes of conduct often become advocacy tools for women’s equal treatment in open-source software online communities."

https://theconversation.com/the-retention-problem-women-are-going-into-tech-but-are-also-being-driven-out-200625

I, um, wrote a 📘 about this stuff if anyone's interested. Tho it's not a best-practices text as much as 1st principles. Ch 3 is about codes of conduct:

https://press.princeton.edu/books/paperback/9780691192888/hacking-diversity

title: Here’s how The Washington Post verified its journalists on Mastodon

last_post.content: Here's how The Washington Post added Mastodon verification with Mastodon's help https://washpost.engineering/heres-how-the-washington-post-verified-its-journalists-on-mastodon-7b5dbc96985c

This is a very in-depth, explanatory article about how biases creep in to supposedly unbiased algorithms when their data sets aren't well designed.
This particular system isn't even a black-box deep learning system, but a complex but reviewable decision tree in which just the parameter weights were set using bad statistics.
Well worth reading.

https://www.wired.com/story/welfare-state-algorithms/

title: In Defense of Studying “Basket Weaving” At College - Clive Thompson - Medium

last_post.content:
This week I wrote in praise of basket weaving as a subject for serious study: https://clivethompson.medium.com/in-defense-of-studying-basket-weaving-at-college-a862792f3a85?sk=05da00e8ad388013630497ce92368ed8

Then @maximum_mew wrote a phenomenal essay riffing off it, describing her own formal education in weaving -- and the wide array of skills, from math to engineering to aesthetics, it required: https://maryewarner.com/2023/03/14/on-the-practicality-of-a-weaving-degree/

And she linked to this fantastic essay by @pluralistic about the Luddites' *actual* relationship to tech -- i.e. "love the machine, hate the factory": https://doctorow.medium.com/gig-work-is-the-opposite-of-steampunk-463e2730ef0d

And at the same time, goodbye to Jason McIntosh, founding board member of IFTF and its first (and up until now only) president.

title: On Star Trek: Discovery and Michelle Yeoh's accent

last_post.content:
I interviewed Michelle Yeoh a few years ago about #StarTrekDiscovery and I mentioned offhand that I'd written an article about what seeing her use her accent on the bridge of a starship meant to me.

She stopped and said "Wait, that was YOU?"

And then proceeded to talk about how much that article had meant to HER and how it contributed to the success of the show.

I can't think about it without crying.

(The original article: https://authory.com/SwapnaKrishna/On-Star-Trek-Discovery-and-Michelle-Yeohs-accent-aa6d2eb01b3a24970abf406c39146df33)

#MichelleYeoh #StarTrek #Oscars

It was an easy prediction to make, given #OpenAI 's track record for sure. Still, I could wish that it wasn't so thoroughly validated.

They are willfully ignoring the most basic risk mitigation strategies, all while proclaiming themselves to be working towards the benefit of humanity.

https://sigmoid.social/@Riedl/110023271456110373

title: Microsoft was already using OpenAI’s GPT-4 model for the Bing AI chatbot

last_post.content:
Bing has been using GPT-4. I guess Microsoft was calling the model Prometheus to avoid admitting it was GPT-4.

https://www.theverge.com/2023/3/14/23639928/microsoft-bing-chatbot-ai-gpt-4-llm

This explains some of Bing's erratic behavior. GPT-4 would have completed training well before ChatGPT was put together, and thus would not have had all the RLHF advances. Microsoft must have also done some of it's own fine-tuning to teach it to respond to Sydney.

Three huge AI announcements this morning:

- Google announced an API for their PaLM language model... but haven't even launched a waitlist for access yet https://developers.googleblog.com/2023/03/announcing-palm-api-and-makersuite.html

- Anthropic announced an API for their Claude model - this time with a waitlist! Which has been in preview in the Quora Poe app for a while now https://www.anthropic.com/index/introducing-claude

- OpenAI announced GPT-4, and made it available for ChatGPT Plus users https://openai.com/product/gpt-4 - but it turns out it's already been powering Bing

Teaching Ethics of Creative AI this term and I am so excited. Added it two weeks before term started, and it filled past capacity. ~40 energized students doing their own critical design projects. Most I've looked forward to a class in years.

Reading list: https://pastebin.com/h8ArZi8U

BREAKING: 🐦InternetArchive supporters are planning a digital rally 3/20 in support of the digital rights of libraries at https://www.battleforlibraries.com/

That's when a judge will hear oral arguments in big publishers' suit to end the ability of libraries to own+preserve digital books.

title: 'GPT-4 to be released this week' - Rockingrobots

last_post.content:
Welp here we fuckin go. GPT-4 is launched.

Back in the run-up to this release, four whole days ago, a bunch of people were talking over on the birdsite about their reactions to the pronouncements of those who'd gotten beta access, and MSFT's own discussions of what they believed it was going to be like.

Everybody in the gpt-4 trend was talking about how much faster it's reported to be, how many more things it can supposedly be applied to, all while blithely glossing over the fact that MSFT itself said that it is *Still Very Often Wrong* (https://www.rockingrobots.com/gpt-4-to-be-released-this-week/).

And that? That is the problem with our technoculture, in a nutshell.

And today, as seen in the image below, we have have these just… incredible scenes, live from OpenAI's GPT-4, where, when Chris Nicholson asked GPT-4 to give him a syllabus and mnemonics for learning Spanish pronunciation, not only did GPT-4 *Get Most Of The Pronunciations Wrong*, but— and I genuinely do not know which of these is worse— *the New York Times Reprinted The Exchange Without Calling This Out*.

I just… Holy shit y'all.

And then add to ALL of that the fact that MSFT just laid off their entire "Ethical A.I." team, in favour of their increasing the workload and making increasingly nebulous the remit of their "Office of Responsible A.I." And they did this right before this the GPT-4 release announcement went wide, specifically citing the pace of development as the reason they were laying their ethicists off (https://gizmodo.com/microsoft-ai-ethical-ai-bing-chatgpt-layoffs-1850223358).

Let me say that again:

Microsoft is laying off their whole "ethical A.I." team specifically BECAUSE they are increasing the range of integrations of their "A.I." tool throughout their *Widely-Used-By-The-U.S.-Government* product ecosystem.

…Which tells me they woefully misunderstand both "Ethics" and "A.I."

I mean this is damn near beyond parody at this point. If I were going to craft a list of shit to absolutely NOT DO in a time like this, it would look pretty much exactly like what OpenAI and MSFT are doing, right now.

Things are about to get real bad, real fast, and you can feel free to quote me on that.

The Atlassian Acceptable Use Policy https://www.atlassian.com/legal/acceptable-use-policy still says they won't allow "Disparaging Atlassian or our partners, vendors, or affiliates". Not limited to "on our Services" -- so, at all, anywhere!

I believe I first noticed this when @robla pointed it out like 10 years ago. Still there, still raises an eyebrow.

Have a good post in the works dropping this weekend.

Subscribe now for free to get it delivered straight to your inbox when it publishes. 👇🏻📫

https://www.beautifulpublicdata.com/#/portal/signup/free

title: Using the NASA Openscapes Framework to enable open science

As @NASA
moves their data over to the Earthdata Cloud, they are leaning on @openscapes
. Openscapes developed a scalable leadership training & community-building framework to support NASA DAAC researchers in migrating workflows to the cloud. Learn more: https://nsidc.org/news-analyses/news-stories/using-nasa-openscapes-framework-enable-open-science

title: PaLM API & MakerSuite: an approachable way to start prototyping and building generative AI applications

last_post.content:
Three huge AI announcements this morning:

- Google announced an API for their PaLM language model... but haven't even launched a waitlist for access yet https://developers.googleblog.com/2023/03/announcing-palm-api-and-makersuite.html

- Anthropic announced an API for their Claude model - this time with a waitlist! Which has been in preview in the Quora Poe app for a while now https://www.anthropic.com/index/introducing-claude

- OpenAI announced GPT-4, and made it available for ChatGPT Plus users https://openai.com/product/gpt-4 - but it turns out it's already been powering Bing

title: A24 in Brandenburg: Tempolimit senkt die Unfallzahlen und fällt deshalb weg

last_post.content:
Ok, das ist wirklich bemerkenswert. Auf einer #Autobahn mit vielen Unfällen wird Tempo 130 eingeführt um das zu senken.

Voller Erfolg, drastische Reduzierung.

Nun wird das Tempolimit wieder aufgehoben, da es ja keine Unfälle mehr gibt.
Und das scheint auch genau so im Sinne des (derzeitigen) Gesetzgebers zu sein.
Wild.

https://www.spiegel.de/auto/brandenburg-tempolimit-auf-a24-senkt-die-unfallzahlen-und-wird-deshalb-aufgehoben-a-105c62ca-f023-4a23-bc0d-9b6242d2593c?dicbo=v2-lzh5tyg

This week I wrote in praise of basket weaving as a subject for serious study: https://clivethompson.medium.com/in-defense-of-studying-basket-weaving-at-college-a862792f3a85?sk=05da00e8ad388013630497ce92368ed8

Then @maximum_mew wrote a phenomenal essay riffing off it, describing her own formal education in weaving -- and the wide array of skills, from math to engineering to aesthetics, it required: https://maryewarner.com/2023/03/14/on-the-practicality-of-a-weaving-degree/

And she linked to this fantastic essay by @pluralistic about the Luddites' *actual* relationship to tech -- i.e. "love the machine, hate the factory": https://doctorow.medium.com/gig-work-is-the-opposite-of-steampunk-463e2730ef0d

You are 30 miles deep in frozen forest on a Soviet dam access road. After struggling to drive you realize you can't make it back before nightfall. You find a metal object melting all the snow around it in a 1 meter radius. It is painfully hot, you cannot even hold it in your bare hands.

You and your friends decide to use it to keep warm.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lia_radiological_accident
